result.execSummary:
The defendant Joshua R. Rabideaux was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Cause Child 13-18 to View Sex. Activity, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.055(1).
  • Exposing Genitals/Pubic Area/Intimate Parts to a Child, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.10(1)(a).
  • Intent. Contribute/Delinquency (Felony), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.40(1).
  • Intent. Contribute/Delinquency (Felony), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.40(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: If probation is discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 50% of gross.
Obtain and maintain full-time employment or schooling or a combination of both equaling full-time as able.

No contact with C.R.C., her family, place of residence/school/employment.
No contact with minor females without prior agent approval.
Any internet usage to be determined and approved by the agent in advance.

Comply with any sex offender treatment assessments and recommendations.
Comply with any recommended psychogical treatment from these evaluations.
Take any medication as recommended by physician.
Comply with any other assessments, treatment, and programming as deemed appropriate by the Compas assessment or the Department of Corrections.
Sign release of information forms for offender's assessments, medication/pharmacies and treatment.
Pay all court ordered obligations in full 90 days prior to discharge, or set up a payment plan, including the DNA surcharge.    
Provide DNA sample if not already completed.

Amendment to Judgment of Conviction /s/ TBE 11/05/19 - Probation extended to 11/11/20 or until he completes the Sex Offender Treatment
   (sent by e-mail to DOC on 11/05/19 sp)

Defendant Joshua R. Rabideaux in court. Prosecuting Assistant District Attorney (ADA) Kristian Mukoski appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Probation Agent Narlock is seated with Counsel.
03:16 PM The Court calls the case and appearances are stated.

There is a request for extension of supervision.

The defendant does not contest the extension.

BY THE COURT:
Supervision extended for a year or until requirements are met.

Letter from the DOC dated 09/25/19 in re:  request to extend probation for 1 year

    Copy of JOC

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: Sent Final Reminder Notice

Defendant Joshua R. Rabideaux in court with attorney John H. Wallace. David R. Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

3:25 pm  Court calls the case. Atty Knaapen states the appearances.
This matter is before the court for sentencing.

Court has received the Department of Corrections Pre-Sentence Investigation.
Atty Knaapen has received the PSI and notes one correction.
Atty Wallace has received the PSI and does not have any corrections.
Court makes correction on his copy of the PSI.

Atty Knaapen makes arguments to the Court re: sentencing recommendations.
Atty Wallace makes arguments to the Court re: sentencing recommendations.
State has complied with Victim Notification Statutes.

BY THE COURT:

Count 3:
Prison Sentence 5 years - 3 years Initial Incarceration and 2 years Extended Supervision - Imposed and Stayed
Not eligible for Challenge Incarceration or Earned Release programs.
PROBATION:  3 years
Conditions of probation:
Comply with the Sex Offender Registry.
No contact with C.R.C., her family, place of residence/school/employment.
No contact with minor females without prior agent approval.
Any internet usage to be determined and approved by the agent in advance.
Comply with any sex offender treatment assessments and recommendations.
Comply with any recommended psychogical treatment from these evaluations.
Take any medication as recommended by physician.
Comply with any other assessments, treatment, and programming as deemed appropriate by the Compas assessment or the Department of Corrections.
Sign release of information forms for offender's assessments, medication/pharmacies and treatment.
Pay all court ordered obligations in full 90 days prior to discharge, or set up a payment plan, including the DNA surcharge.   
Obtain/maintain employment and/or schooling or a combination of both equal to fulltime as able.   
Provide DNA sample if not already completed.

Count 4:
Jail Sentence 60 days - first 30 in followed by 30 days on home monitoring program if qualify.
Huber privileges
60 days to start the sentence
Report to the jail today to set up the start time.
Pay costs, including the DNA surcharge.
60 days to pay fine and costs, or set up a payment
0 days jail credit

Count 6:
Prison Sentence 5 years - 3 years Initial Incarceration and 2 years Extended Supervision - Imposed and Stayed, concurrent with Count 3 
Not eligible for Challenge Incarceration or Earned Release programs.
PROBATION:  3 years, concurrent with Count 3

Count 7:
Prison Sentence 5 years - 3 years Initial Incarceration and 2 years Extended Supervision - Imposed and Stayed, concurrent with Counts 3 & 6
Not eligible for Challenge Incarceration or Earned Release programs.
PROBATION:  3 years, concurrent with Counts 3 & 6

Court provides a written determination of prison sentence to Defendant.
Atty Wallace to go over appeals rights with the Defendant.
20 days in which to appeal.

4:06 pm  Case concluded.

records.addlTxt: Sentencing hearing on November 11, 2016 at 03:00 pm.

Defendant Joshua R. Rabideaux in court with attorney John H. Wallace. David R. Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

10:43 a.m.  Atty Knaapen calls the case and states the appearances.

Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Prosecutor states plea agreement.
Attorney for Defendant concurs with agreement stated.

Defendant enters a plea of: 
Count 1 - DRI
Count 2 - DRI
Count 3 - No contest
Count 4 - No contest 
Count 5 - DRI
Count 6 - No contest 
Count 7 - No contest 
Count 8 - DRI
Count 9 - DRI

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty on Count 3, 4, 6 & 7 and Count 1, 2, 5, 8 & 9 are DRI.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.

BY THE COURT:
PSI ordered. 
PSI to be provided to the parties at least 1 week prior to the sentencing date.
Bond is continued.  Sentencing hearing scheduled for November 11, 2016 at 03:00 pm.
Plea hearing on August 5, 2016 at 10:30 am.

4:27 p.m. Defendant Joshua R. Rabideaux in court with attorney John H. Wallace. Cass W Cousins appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant waives right to Preliminary Hearing.

Court questions Defendant's attorney.
Court finds the Defendant has freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived the Preliminary Hearing.
On the defendants waiver of the preliminary hearing, Court determines, based on the facts contained in the complaint, there is sufficient probable cause and binds the defendant over for trial.
